**G.L. c. 218, \u00a719**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19** and **G.L. c. 223, §2**, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $25,000 and the property that is the subject of this action is located within this division.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a72**.proposition: Venue is proper in the **Cambridge District Court** under **G.L. c. 223, §2**, because the defendant resides or does business in Cambridge and the events giving rise to this action occurred within this judicial district.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a714**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, every tenancy in Massachusetts carries an implied covenant that the landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from acts or omissions that “substantially interfere with a tenant’s tenancy by materially impairing the character and value of the leased premises.” *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The quoted proposition is not stated in this opinion. Al‑Ziab concerns whether a statutory violation (the lead paint statute) automatically constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that at least negligent conduct with notice is required under G.L. c. 186, § 14. While the case discusses fault, foreseeability, and examples of conditions that interfere with quiet enjoyment, it does not articulate a general standard that the covenant protects against acts or omissions that ‘substantially interfere with a tenant’s tenancy by materially impairing the character and value of the leased premises.’
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Actions constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment include **excessive noise, dust, construction activity, and other disturbances** that render the premises unsuitable for their intended purpose. *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 718–719 (1977).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion in Lowery v. Robinson concerns failure to provide heat as a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not discuss excessive noise, dust, construction activity, or other disturbances; its contribution is to confirm that lack of heat during the heating season constitutes a serious impairment and thus a breach. Therefore, citing Lowery for the broader proposition about noise, dust, and construction rendering premises unsuitable is inaccurate; that broader content comes from Blackett, not Lowery.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: Actions constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment include **excessive noise, dust, construction activity, and other disturbances** that render the premises unsuitable for their intended purpose. *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 718–719 (1977).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that excessive noise from a nearby lounge, which substantially deprived residential tenants of quiet enjoyment and made the premises not reasonably habitable, constitutes a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and a constructive eviction. While Blackett deals specifically with noise rather than dust or construction, the reasoning clearly treats serious disturbances that are the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s actions or omissions as actionable breaches, fitting within the broader formulation used in the proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’… He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises… The landlords do not challenge the judge’s conclusion that the noise emanating from the lounge was sufficient to constitute a constructive eviction… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did… they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: A landlord’s failure to control conditions created by the landlord or by others under the landlord’s control—such as construction crews—constitutes a breach of this covenant. *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s duties to maintain habitable, watertight premises and to prevent flooding, and it rejects the landlord’s attempt to blame third parties, but it does not frame this in terms of a “failure to control conditions created by the landlord or by others under the landlord’s control, such as construction crews.” The case involves flooding from waste stacks and a porous wall, not conditions caused by construction crews or similar actors, and the key holding is about breach of warranty of habitability and interference with quiet enjoyment, not specifically about control over contractors or others under the landlord’s control. Thus the quoted proposition overstates and mischaracterizes what Simon v. Solomon actually holds.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control. … This contention echoes Gem’s objections to the verdict for reckless infliction of emotional distress, and we reject it for the same reasons. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).”}

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: A breach of the covenant does not require intentional misconduct where the landlord’s acts or omissions foreseeably cause substantial interference. *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court’s quiet-enjoyment analysis explicitly states that liability depends on whether the serious interference with the tenancy is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and that the landlord’s intentions are irrelevant. This makes clear that intentional misconduct is not required; foreseeable substantial interference resulting from the landlord’s acts or omissions can constitute a breach. The remand is to determine what measures were or were not taken, not whether the landlord intended the interference.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872.proposition: The landlord cannot avoid liability merely by offering minimal rent reductions, particularly where the interference continues and is significant. *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872 (1991).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872.support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Gonzalez does not discuss whether a landlord can avoid liability by offering minimal rent reductions or abatements in the face of ongoing, significant interference. The damages discussion focuses on the correct measure for breach of the implied warranty of habitability (using fair market value rather than contract rent) and explicitly rejects the idea that a landlord can nullify the warranty by charging discounted rent, but it does not address the specific concept of minimal rent reductions as a defense to liability for ongoing interference. Thus the proposition, as phrased, is not directly supported by this case.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 872.relevant_excerpt: “The fact that Gonzalez agreed to pay less for the apartment than its full value as warranted is not controlling. The rule for computation of damages in this area gives a tenant no more than the benefit of the bargain because the implied warranty of habitability is part of the bargain. A landlord cannot nullify the implied warranty of habitability on a dwelling by giving his tenant a discount in rent.”

*Winchester v. McCue*, 91 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is distinct from any implied warranty of habitability, but non-physical disturbances such as noise and dust may still justify damages. *Winchester v. McCue*, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 289, 293 (2017).

*Caines v. Commonwealth*, 49 Mass. App..proposition: Listed in the Complaint's Table of Authorities (Cited Statutes and Cases).
*Caines v. Commonwealth*, 49 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The proposition is described only as “Listed in the Complaint's Table of Authorities (Cited Statutes and Cases),” which does not specify any actual legal principle. Without knowing the specific proposition this case is being cited to support, I cannot reliably determine whether the opinion’s holdings about probable cause, informant basis of knowledge, staleness, or warrant particularity align with that proposition. The case clearly addresses those issues, but the match to the unspecified proposition cannot be evaluated.
*Caines v. Commonwealth*, 49 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In order to establish probable cause, an affidavit must contain sufficient information for an issuing magistrate to determine that the items sought are related to the criminal activity under investigation, and that the items reasonably may be expected to be located in the place to be searched at the time the warrant issues. … It is well established that an informant’s basis of knowledge may be satisfied simply by his or her personal observation of drugs in the place sought to be searched such as the defendant’s apartment.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Listed in the Complaint's Table of Authorities (Cited Statutes and Cases).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition is described only as "Listed in the Complaint's Table of Authorities (Cited Statutes and Cases)," which is too vague to identify any specific legal principle the case is supposedly supporting. Young v. Patukonis discusses several discrete issues (sanitary code heat/hot water obligations, security deposit treble damages, Boston rent control remedies, habitability damages, and c. 93A inapplicability to an owner-occupant), but without knowing which of these the complaint relies on, I cannot reliably confirm support. Because the proposition is undefined, I must conclude it is not shown to be supported.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
Young, as an owner-occupant of a three-family building, whose primary objective is personal, is not subject to G. L. c. 93A. That claim was properly dismissed. See Billings v. Wilson, 397 Mass. 614 (1986).

The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant. See Mellor v. Berman, 390 Mass. 275, 280 (1983).

*Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr..raw_text: *Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr. v. Cambridge Point, LLC*, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) (discussing landlord responsibility for foreseeability of harm).
*Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Tr..proposition: Listed in the Complaint's Table of Authorities (Cited Statutes and Cases).
